docs.snippet: President Jorge Batlle has made an unplanned, emergency trip to Buenos Aires to apologize to his Argentine counterpart, Eduardo Duhalde, for remarks broadcast on Monday in which Mr. Batlle, left, called Argentina's politicians ''a pack of thieves,...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Jorge Batlle has made an unplanned, emergency trip to Buenos Aires to apologize to his Argentine counterpart, Eduardo Duhalde, for remarks broadcast on Monday in which Mr. Batlle, left, called Argentina's politicians ''a pack of thieves, from the first to the last.'' Uruguay has been severely hit by fallout from Argentina's economic crisis, and Mr. Batlle had complained in the same interview that Mr. Duhalde ''has no political power or backing and doesn't know where he's heading.'' On his visit, he tearfully begged Argentines for forgiveness. Larry Rohter (NYT)
docs.abstract: Pres Jorge Batlle of Uruguay makes unplanned, emergency trip to Buenos Aires to apologize to his Argentine counterpart, Eduardo Duhalde, for calling Argentina's politicians a pack of thieves and saying Duhalde has no political power or backing and does not know where he is heading; photo (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: An Apology To Argentina

docs.snippet: In a rough-and-tumble match edged with a certain desperation on both sides, France and Uruguay played to a scoreless tie tonight that left both teams still in the running for the second round in the World Cup.    For the French, the match again...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a rough-and-tumble match edged with a certain desperation on both sides, France and Uruguay played to a scoreless tie tonight that left both teams still in the running for the second round in the World Cup. For the French, the match again demonstrated how far the team has fallen since it won the World Cup four years ago. The team that scored seven goals in its first two matches before the home fans in France in 1998 has failed to put a ball into the net in its first two matches in South Korea against teams that it was expected to dominate.
docs.abstract: French national team has yet to score goal after two matches in World Cup, just four years after dominating powerhouse teams to win Cup; chart tracks progress of World Cup (M)

headline.main: France, Still Scoreless, Can Only Tie

docs.snippet: David Trezeguet's body language told it all. After hitting the crossbar in the 74th minute, he lifted his palms to the sky and smiled meekly, as if to say, ''What can you do?''    The French could do little today; they could do little at this World...
docs.lead_paragraph: David Trezeguet's body language told it all. After hitting the crossbar in the 74th minute, he lifted his palms to the sky and smiled meekly, as if to say, ''What can you do?'' The French could do little today; they could do little at this World Cup. And now they are gone. The defending champions were knocked out at the end of the opening round by losing to Denmark, 2-0.
docs.abstract: France, World Cup defending champion, is eliminated from competition with 2-0 loss to Denmark; team becomes first defending champion to not reach second round since 1966; photo (M)

headline.main: France Plays Like Old Man Of Europe

docs.snippet: It made Page 1 of the nation's most prestigious newspaper. It plunged spectators clustered around television screens in homes and boulevard cafes into grief and immense Gallic shrugs. But, ultimately, said one French student who watched his national...
docs.lead_paragraph: It made Page 1 of the nation's most prestigious newspaper. It plunged spectators clustered around television screens in homes and boulevard cafes into grief and immense Gallic shrugs. But, ultimately, said one French student who watched his national team's exit from the World Cup on his computer screen here today, it was ''the story of a death foretold.'' France, the world soccer champion, had lost 2-0 to lowly Denmark. France, the team held in thrall by the star player Zinedine Zidane, was out. Its performance did not even carry it from the first round or notch up a single goal in three games against Senegal, Uruguay and the Danes.
docs.abstract: Mood across France is glum and disbelieving after world champion national soccer team falls into ignominious defeat at this year's World Cup (S)

headline.main: In France, Cheers for Soccer Champions Fade Into Stony Silence

docs.snippet: THE year-old Istanbul Kebab House in Lynbrook serves humble, working-class ethnic food. More earthy than elegant, the walls at this double storefront at 88 Atlantic Avenue (516-596-6800) are festooned with lanterns, hanging carpets, musical...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE year-old Istanbul Kebab House in Lynbrook serves humble, working-class ethnic food. More earthy than elegant, the walls at this double storefront at 88 Atlantic Avenue (516-596-6800) are festooned with lanterns, hanging carpets, musical instruments, water pipes, Ali Baba-like silver slippers with red pompoms, oversize eating utensils and decorative dishes from the Middle East. There's a belly dancer on the scene every Saturday night, the hot Turkish bread is terrific and a special of whole fish costs just $15.
docs.abstract: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Istanbul Kebab House restaurant in Lynbrook, NY (A La Carte column) (M)

docs.snippet: At 3 a.m. Tuesday, Camara Mabinty ran from Kaloum, the Guinean restaurant she owns on West 116th Street in Harlem, to Le Baobab, the Senegalese restaurant a few doors down. Senegal had just surged to a 3-0 lead over Uruguay in a crucial World Cup...
docs.lead_paragraph: At 3 a.m. Tuesday, Camara Mabinty ran from Kaloum, the Guinean restaurant she owns on West 116th Street in Harlem, to Le Baobab, the Senegalese restaurant a few doors down. Senegal had just surged to a 3-0 lead over Uruguay in a crucial World Cup match, and restaurants and barbershops in this West African enclave roared with soccer fans. ''Trois-zéro! Trois-zéro!'' Ms. Mabinty shouted, using the French that serves as a common language for Senegal, Guinea and other former French West African colonies whose citizens were rooting for the Senegal team. At Le Baobab, where a dozen Senegalese watched the live broadcast from Suwon, South Korea, high-fives, hugs and shouts in Wolof and French had been de rigueur throughout the game's first half.
docs.abstract: Scene at Le Baobab, Senegalese restaurant on West 116th Street, described as Senegalese soccer fans root for their team during World Cup match; photo (M)

headline.main: An Unexpected Pleasure For the City's Senegalese

docs.snippet: The government of Uruguay announced today that it would allow the country's currency, the peso, to float freely against the American dollar, in an effort to soften the blow of a deepening regional economic crisis.    The change in policy, though not...
docs.lead_paragraph: The government of Uruguay announced today that it would allow the country's currency, the peso, to float freely against the American dollar, in an effort to soften the blow of a deepening regional economic crisis. The change in policy, though not unexpected, immediately unleashed a heavy demand for dollars, with Uruguayans rushing to exchange houses in Montevideo, the capital. In the first few hours of panicky trading, the value of the Uruguayan peso dropped by nearly 20 percent against the dollar.
docs.abstract: Uruguay Government announces that it will allow country's currency, peso, to float freely against American dollar, in effort to soften blow of deepening regional economic crisis; policy change immediately unleashes heavy demand for dollars; photo of Economy Min Alberto Bension (M)

headline.main: Uruguay Lifts Limits on Peso to Assist Economy

docs.snippet: Court Upholds State Review Of Health Care Decisions  The Supreme Court has upheld the states' authority to protect the rights of patients in disputes with managed care companies over denial of recommended treatments. Such protections, guaranteeing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Court Upholds State Review Of Health Care Decisions The Supreme Court has upheld the states' authority to protect the rights of patients in disputes with managed care companies over denial of recommended treatments. Such protections, guaranteeing outside review of a health plan's refusal to pay for a procedure, are the centerpiece of the federal patients' rights bill that has passed both houses of Congress in different versions but remains stalled there. Patients' advocates said the 5-to-4 decision did not eliminate the need for Congressional action because state laws excluded millions of people who could be protected only through federal legislation. [Page A1.]

docs.snippet: The president of Argentina's central bank will continue to help the government negotiate a resumption of International Monetary Fund aid despite his decision to quit, President Eduardo Duhalde of Argentina said on Saturday.    The central bank...
docs.lead_paragraph: The president of Argentina's central bank will continue to help the government negotiate a resumption of International Monetary Fund aid despite his decision to quit, President Eduardo Duhalde of Argentina said on Saturday. The central bank president, Mario Blejer, who is stepping down from his central bank post at the end of the month, is a former monetary fund official is who considered by investors as the best guarantee for orthodox monetary policies in Argentina's economy.
docs.abstract: Mario Blejer, president of Argentina's central bank, will continue to help government negotiate resumption of International Monetary Fund aid despite his decision to quit (S)

headline.main: Argentina Says I.M.F. Talks Will Resume

docs.snippet: The president says it may be impossible to reach any agreement with the International Monetary Fund, the head of the central bank is giving up and going home, and the economy minister embarked tonight on a desperate quest to pry $18 billion from...
docs.lead_paragraph: The president says it may be impossible to reach any agreement with the International Monetary Fund, the head of the central bank is giving up and going home, and the economy minister embarked tonight on a desperate quest to pry $18 billion from foreign lenders. For Argentina, an already disastrous economic crisis is suddenly threatening to become even more calamitous.
docs.abstract: Argentina's already disastrous economic crisis is suddenly threatening to become even worse; Pres Eduardo Duhalde says it may be impossible to reach any agreement with International Monetary Fund; central bank president Mario Blejer is stepping down; will be replaced by Aldo Piganelli; Blejer's departure leaves Economic Min Roberto Lavagna as undisputed chief of government's economic team; Lavagna embarks on three days of meeting with country's creditors in New York and Washington to get $18 billion from lenders; Argentine peso is down 2.5 percent, to 3.86 to dollar;

headline.main: Blows Keep Coming for an Argentina Long in Crisis
